senses.de: To strongly advise or try to persuade someone to do a particular thing.
senses.ex: The doctor urged me to lose weight for the sake of my health.

Tips.title: Strong Advice
Tips.description: Use 'urge' to express strong recommendations, often more forceful than a simple suggestion.
Tips.example: The council urged residents to evacuate before the hurricane.

Tips.title: Persuasive Tone
Tips.description: The word 'urge' conveys a sense of urgency and importance when advising someone.
Tips.example: Environmentalists urge the public to reduce plastic waste.

Tips.title: Formal Contexts
Tips.description: 'Urge' is often used in formal or professional contexts, such as health or safety advice.
Tips.example: Officials urge citizens to follow the new regulations.

senses.de: A strong wish or need to do something.
senses.ex: I felt an urge to jump into the lake, even though it was cold.

Tips.title: Inner Desire
Tips.description: 'Urge' as a noun describes a strong internal feeling that compels you to act.
Tips.example: Despite his diet, he had a sudden urge for ice cream.

Tips.title: Sudden Impulse
Tips.description: An 'urge' can come on suddenly and be overwhelming, itching for immediate action.
Tips.example: Out of nowhere, she felt an urge to call her old friend.

Tips.title: Fight or Indulge
Tips.description: Urge portrays a struggle between resisting a desire or giving in to it.
Tips.example: He fought the urge to check his phone during the meeting.

senses.de: To move or push someone or something in a particular direction gently or forcefully.
senses.ex: The police had to urge the crowd back to keep them safe.

Tips.title: Guide Gently
Tips.description: As a verb, 'urge' can mean to guide or encourage someone gently towards a direction or action.
Tips.example: The guide urged us forward to see the hidden waterfall.

Tips.title: Physical Prompt
Tips.description: It can also imply a physical push, but not as violent as a shove.
Tips.example: He urged the sheep back into the pen with a gentle tap.

Tips.title: Indirect Force
Tips.description: 'Urge' indicates using some force but in an indirect or non-physical way.
Tips.example: The speaker urged the audience to their feet with an inspiring speech.

Encourage.wordDefinition:
Encourage means to give support, confidence or hope to someone.

For example, "I encouraged my friend to keep trying despite the setbacks."

So, while both ‘encourage’ and ‘urge’ have the same goal to motivate someone to do something, ‘encourage’ focuses on more emotional support, while ‘urge’ is more intent on pushing someone to make immediate decisions or take specific action.

Exhort.wordDefinition: Exhort means to strongly encourage or urge someone to do something with enthusiasm, motivation or passion. It is applicable in situations where there is a need for persuasion or inspiration, like motivating someone to work harder or inspiring them to follow their dreams.

Impel.wordDefinition:
Impel and urge are both verbs that describe an action of prompting or encouraging someone to do something.

Impel means to force or drive someone to do something. It often implies a sense of urgency or necessity. For example, "The fear of danger impelled her to run away.".

The difference is that impel implies a stronger force or influence to act, while urge is more of a persuasion or encouragement.

Both verbs can be used in various situations, but impel is often used in more serious or urgent circumstances, while urge can be used in any situation where you want to motivate someone to take action.

Instigate.wordDefinition:
Both instigate and urge refer to encouraging someone to take a certain action or decision.

Instigate generally has a negative connotation and implies causing or provoking someone to do something harmful or wrong, such as instigating a fight or instigating a rebellion.

The difference between the two words lies in the intent behind the encouragement: instigate suggests a negative intent, while urge suggests a positive intent.

Nudge.wordDefinition:
Both nudge and urge refer to encouraging someone to take action or make a decision, but they differ in intensity and approach.

A nudge is a gentle suggestion or prompt, often given indirectly or subtly, to influence someone's behavior without seeming pushy or bossy.

For example, a parent might nudge their child to study by leaving a book on their desk or mentioning how proud they'll be if they do well on a test.

Overall, nudging is generally milder and more subtle, while urging is more forceful and direct. Which one you use depends on your relationship with the person, the situation, and the tone or message you want to convey.

Persuade.wordDefinition:
Persuade means to convince or influence a person to do or believe something. It involves presenting logical arguments, evidence or giving reasons that make someone change their mind.

For example: The salesman tried to persuade me to buy the car by showing its features.

In summary, while both words are used to convince someone to take action or believe in something, persuade is more comprehensive as it involves convincing someone through logical reasoning while urge is more forceful and vigorous, involving an appeal for immediate action.

Press.wordDefinition:
Press means to push or direct forcefully towards a certain action or outcome. It is applicable when someone wants to emphasize the importance or urgency of something.

For example, "I press you to finish your homework before going out with your friends."

Prod.wordDefinition:
Prod means to encourage or push someone to take action or do something. It's usually used when you want someone to act faster or do something they might not want to do.

For example, you might prod your friend to study for their exam.

Prod is more about pushing or motivating someone to take action, while urge is more about strongly advising someone to take action based on the importance of the situation.

Prompt.wordDefinition:
Prompt means to encourage or remind someone to do something. For example, a teacher might prompt their students to raise their hands before speaking in class.

Prompt is used when you want someone to remember to do something, while urge is used when you want someone to take action on something important.

quotes.Text: Right now, I don't have the same urges as other women when they see a baby. When I see children, I see responsibilities, which I don't think I'm quite ready for. I feel the same about puppies. They're cute for a second, but there's a lot of responsibility involved.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Gabrielle Union

quotes.Text: I think it is very important that I should have a talk with you as soon as possible on a highly secret matter. I mentioned it to you shortly after you took office but have not urged it since on account of the pressure you have been under.
quotes.Title: American Statesman
quotes.Name: Henry L. Stimson

quotes.Text: People that I have known that have been extremely creative, people in the business, they have always been influenced by their mothers. Their mothers are the ones that created whatever it is - the urge to create.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Georgia Holt

quotes.Text: The urge that most people feel to have kids is the exact same as the urge that I have to not have kids. I do not want to raise a child.
quotes.Title: American Comedian
quotes.Name: Jen Kirkman

quotes.Text: It is so hard to make important decisions that we have a great urge to reduce them to rules.
quotes.Title: Canadian Philosopher
quotes.Name: Ian Hacking

quotes.Text: Way down deep, we're all motivated by the same urges. Cats have the courage to live by them.
quotes.Title: American Cartoonist
quotes.Name: Jim Davis

quotes.Text: The urge to save humanity is almost always a false front for the urge to rule.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: H. L. Mencken

quotes.Text: I adore tattoos. They're not painful; you just get an urge to swear a lot.
quotes.Title: English Actress
quotes.Name: Finty Williams

quotes.Text: I urge my critics to get passports and see the world.
quotes.Title: American Public Servant
quotes.Name: Michael Caputo

quotes.Text: I'm afraid I have an incurable urge for teaching.
quotes.Title: Spanish Writer
quotes.Name: Antonio Munoz Molina
